required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Calcium Phosphate Versus PMMA Cement in Thoracolumbar Fractures
clinical_study.official_title: Calcium Phosphate Versus PMMA Cement in Unstable Thoracolumbar Burst Fractures Treated With Dorsal Instrumentation in Patients > 50 Years of Age Randomized Controlled Non-inferiority Trial Design

brief_summary.textblock: Patients at the age of 50 or older presenting with thoracolumbar fractures including segments TH 6-L5 and A3/A4 fractures according to the AO Spine fracture classification after the acute trauma and planned surgery within 3 weeks following trauma will be asked to participate in a randomized trial in which they will receive either Calciumphosphate (CaP) or Polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) as part of a standardized treatment approach. Regardless of the group patients are randomized to, all participating patients undergo the same surgical procedure except for the preparation and administration of bone cement. The study participation period for each patient is 1 year from the date of the surgery and includes 4 defined time points that include follow-up clinical visits for imaging and progress checks at 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months and 12 months after surgery. At each follow-up visit, a combination of questionnaires and radiological imaging will be performed to assess general health status, disability level and pain control, as well as objective results of the surgery. The main outcome measure will be the loss of correction rate that will be measured through the bi-segmental COBB angle presented in the CT-scan.

study_design_info.masking_description: Patients and study nurse will be blinded to treatment allocation; however, surgeons cannot be blinded due to different techniques of bone cement application. A centralized and automated internet-based randomization system will ensure concealed randomization of study participants. Participants will be the unit of randomization. Randomization will be carried out with randomizer.at and will occur prior to the surgical procedure.

primary_outcome.measure: The change in correction rates when using CaP
primary_outcome.time_frame: Preoperatively (determination of fracture classification), postoperatively (immediately following surgery), 1 year postoperatively
primary_outcome.description: The main outcome measure 1 will be the loss of correction rate that will be measured through the bi-segmental COBB angle presented in the CT-scan. The Cobb angle will be measured between the superior end plate of the vertebral body cephalad to the injury and the inferior end plate of the vertebral body caudal to the injury.

primary_outcome.measure: The change in correction rates when using PMMA
primary_outcome.time_frame: Preoperatively (determination of fracture classification), postoperatively (immediately following surgery), 1 year postoperatively
primary_outcome.description: The main outcome 2 measure will be the loss of correction rate that will be measured through the bi-segmental COBB angle presented in the CT-scan. The Cobb angle will be measured between the superior end plate of the vertebral body cephalad to the injury and the inferior end plate of the vertebral body caudal to the injury. Measurements will be taken from CT scans.

secondary_outcome.measure: The change in vertebral body height when using CaP
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Preoperatively, postoperatively (immediately following the surgery), 1 year postoperatively
secondary_outcome.description: The percentage loss of the vertebral body height will be calculated by dividing the height of the fractured vertebra by the average height of the cephalad and caudad vertebrae and then subtracting this number from 100%. Measurements will be taken from CT scans.

secondary_outcome.measure: The change in vertebral body height when using PMMA
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Preoperatively, postoperatively (immediately following the surgery), 1 year postoperatively
secondary_outcome.description: The percentage loss of the vertebral body height will be calculated by dividing the height of the fractured vertebra by the average height of the cephalad and caudad vertebrae and then subtracting this number from 100%.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in complication rates when using PMMA
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months and 12 months postoperatively
secondary_outcome.description: The occurence of the complication rates, in particular cement extravasation and temporary fall in blood pressure, will be compared between the two groups for each time point using the Student´s t-test for independent samples. In addition, a paired Student´s t-test will be performed within each group in order to evaluate the differences in means of the secondary endpoints measured at the defined timepoints.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in complication rates when using CaP
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months and 12 months postoperatively
secondary_outcome.description: The occurence of the complication rates, in particular cement extravasation and temporary fall in blood pressure, will be compared between the two groups for each time point using the Student´s t-test for independent samples. In addition, a paired Student´s t-test will be performed within each group in order to evaluate the differences in means of the secondary endpoints measured at the defined timepoints.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the disability on the ODI rating scale in patients with PMMA
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Five times - after the surgery, at each study visit (6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months and 12 months postoperatively)
secondary_outcome.description: ODI is mainly used in spine trauma patients. A score of 0% to 20% indicates minimal disability; 21% to 40%, moderate disability; and 41% to 60% severe disability.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the disability on the ODI rating scale in patients with CaP
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Five times - after the surgery, at each study visit (6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months and 12 months postoperatively)
secondary_outcome.description: ODI is mainly used in spine trauma patients. A score of 0% to 20% indicates minimal disability; 21% to 40%, moderate disability; and 41% to 60% severe disability.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in pain on the spine VAS in patients with PMMA
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Five times - after the surgery, at each study visit (6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months and 12 months postoperatively)
secondary_outcome.description: VAS - Spine Visual Analogue Scale is a measurement that measures pain intensity and it is completed by patients themselves.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in pain on the spine VAS in patients with CaP
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Five times - after the surgery, at each study visit (6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months and 12 months postoperatively)
secondary_outcome.description: VAS - Spine Visual Analogue Scale is a measurement that measures pain intensity and it is completed by patients themselves.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in quality of life in patients with PMMA measured by the 36-item Short Form Survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Five times - after the surgery, at each study visit (6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months and 12 months postoperatively)
secondary_outcome.description: The 36-Item Short Form Survey (SF-36) will be used to assess patient´s self-reported quality of life.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in quality of life in patients with CaP measured by the 36-item Short Form Survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Five times - after the surgery, at each study visit (6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months and 12 months postoperatively)
secondary_outcome.description: The 36-Item Short Form Survey (SF-36) will be used to assess patient´s self-reported quality of life.

arm_group.arm_group_label: KYPHON® ActivOs™10 Bone Cement with hydroxyapatite
arm_group.description: As a reference device KYPHON® ActivOs™10 Bone Cement with hydroxyapatite (Medtronic) for treatment of vertebral compression fractures will be used. It is a polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) bone cement containing hydroxyapatite (HA) for use in the treatment of patients with vertebral compression fractures (VCFs) who are undergoing minimally invasive surgery with KYPHON® Balloon Kyphoplasty. This bone substitute has already been approved and is in use in the patients at the age of 50 or older.
The test device KyphOs FS™ will be used in patients at the age of 50 and older in order to prove its superiority over the currently used PMMA bone cement.

intervention.description: Dorsal instrumentation via Longitude II (Medtronic Austria GmbH/Vienna) and balloon kyphoplasty are performed. KyphOs FS™ bone cement will be introduced in the fractured vertebral body.
intervention.other_name: KyphOs FS™ Medtronic Spine LLC, Minneapolis, MN, USA

intervention.intervention_name: KYPHON ActivOs® Bone Cement with Hydroxyapatite
intervention.description: Dorsal instrumentation via Longitude II (Medtronic Austria GmbH/Vienna) and balloon kyphoplasty are performed. KYPHON ActivOs® Bone Cement with Hydroxyapatite will be introduced in the fractured vertebral body.
intervention.arm_group_label: KYPHON® ActivOs™10 Bone Cement with hydroxyapatite
intervention.other_name: KYPHON ActivOs® Bone Cement with Hydroxyapatite, Medtronic Spine LLC, Minneapolis, MN, USA

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Written consent of the participant after being informed
- Acute trauma (surgery within three weeks following trauma)
- Thoracolumbar fractures including segments TH 6-L5
- A3/A4 fractures according to the AO Spine fracture classification
- Patient age ≥ 50 years
- Minimum follow up 1 year
Exclusion Criteria:
- Presence of neurological deficits at the time of surgery
- Pathological fractures (bone metastases)
- Traumatic brain injury
- Ankylosing spondylitis as a comorbidity
- Pregnancy

patient_data.ipd_description: Results of the study are planned to be made public within a scientific work.
